docs.lead_paragraph: LAST winter, Tammy Guthrie, a 40-year-old mother of three from St. Petersburg, Fla., took a brief leave of absence from her family to undergo some self-improvement in Los Angeles. Five and a half weeks later, she returned, reawakened, to her husband and her three children, all in elementary school. ''Throughout my marriage, I'd taken a passive role, thinking that was what my husband wanted,'' Ms. Guthrie said. Now, three months after coming home, she said: ''I'm no longer afraid of his reactions. I'm not bothered if he doesn't agree with me, and, surprisingly, I think he likes it.''
docs.abstract: Article on reactions of some otherwise ordinary people who have undergone radical and near-instant personal transformations after having surgery for reality television show Extreme Makeover; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The town dump here may not look like much of a soapbox, but Michael Gilbertie leaps out of his folding chair like a man half his age when cars pull up with their trash. When the subject is taxes, every trip to the dump is suddenly an exercise in democracy. Wearing a smile and an American flag pinned to his chest, Mr. Gilbertie, 63, politely asks the drivers if they would like to ''help get taxes reduced.'' Parents of school-age children tend to give him the hardest time, often saying they support higher taxes if the money goes to schools. But others, like Richard Auber, readily sign Mr. Gilbertie's petition. They seem happy to support his drive for a town referendum on whether to shrink next year's $128.6 million budget by $5 million.

headline.main: Westport Journal; Where to Find a Local Gadfly? Battling Against Taxes at the Town Dump

docs.abstract: Michael Gilbertie is collecting signatures of Westport, Conn, residents in effort to reduce town's $128.6 million budget next year by $5 million; he needs 1,593 signatures to force referendum; profile; map; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The town dump here may not look like much of a soapbox, but Michael Gilbertie leaps out of his folding chair like a man half his age when cars pull up with their trash. When the subject is taxes, every trip to the dump is suddenly an exercise in...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush declared himself a candidate for re-election today, filing papers that allow him to begin raising money and put a campaign staff in place for a race that his advisers say will hinge on whether he can revive the economy and protect the nation from terrorism. After months in which it said Mr. Bush was ignoring electoral politics to focus on the war with Iraq and pushing his tax cut through Congress, the White House pulled back the curtain today on a campaign operation that plans to send out one million fund-raising letters in the next few days, has a Web site up and running and has assembled a group of top officials ready to start work.

headline.main: Candidate Bush Files Papers for '04 Race

docs.abstract: Pres Bush declares self candidate for re-election, filing papers that let him begin raising money and forming campaign staff; unveils campaign operation; plans to move quickly to raise funds, beginning with June fund-raiser; campaign officials plan heavy schedule of appearances this year for Vice Pres Dick Cheney; dispute reports they intend to raise $200 million or more to finance campaign through Republican convention next summer; say goal will be closer to $100 million; Karl Rove, architect of re-election plan, will remain on White House staff; Bush names Ken Mehlman as campaign manager; Mercer Reynolds will be finance chairman; Jack Oliver will run campaign's fund-raising operations day to day as deputy finance chairman; Republicans say Marc Racicot will probably leave as Republican National Committee chairman to become campaign chairman; White House says Bush will forgo federal matching funds during primary (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential contenders agree about what they predict will be a central issue next year, rebuilding a health care system that many Americans say is in turmoil. But increasingly they disagree over how to do it.

headline.main: Kerry Introduces Health Plan, Pointing Up Divisions Among Democratic Contenders

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry, campaigning in Iowa, is latest Democratic presidential contender to propose health care plan; stresses cutting costs and insurance premiums while expanding coverage to 95 percent of Americans; criticizes Rep Richard A Gephardt's plan as too expensive, but says his long-term goal would be to cover entire nation; he and Dr Howard Dean favor eliminating just some tax cuts to finance their programs; aspects of Gephardt and Kerry plans are potentially attractive to union leaders; Gephardt also campaigns in Iowa; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Democratic presidential contenders agree about what they predict will be a central issue next year, rebuilding a health care system that many Americans say is in turmoil.    But increasingly they disagree over how to do it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several thousand New Jersey doctors and nurses staged their second rally of the year here today to press their demand for legislation to limit jury awards in malpractice lawsuits. Chanting, waving placards and wearing their white lab coats, the doctors crowded onto State Street, in front of the State House, to hear speakers urge the General Assembly to pass a tort-reform bill that would limit awards for pain and suffering to $1 million, and insurers' liability for such awards to $300,000. The bill was passed by the State Senate in March.

headline.main: Doctors Rally for Limits on Awards in Malpractice Suits

docs.abstract: Several thousand New Jersey doctors and nurses stage their second rally of year, Trenton, to press their demand for legislation to limit jury awards in malpractice lawsuits; photo (M)

docs.abstract: Manuel Haendler letter says that as one of nearly 60 millions Americans who lack health insurance he takes note of Vice Pres Cheney's recent statement of how seriously he takes medical attention, by having 'doc with me 24 hours a day' (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tenet Healthcare, the hospital operator, reported yesterday that it had a first-quarter loss after it changed its policy for billing the government for the sickest patients. After a government investigation into Tenet's reimbursement practices, the company adopted a new policy for billing ''outlier payments,'' which are special Medicare payments made to health care providers for patients who incur unusually high costs.

headline.main: Tenet Healthcare Posts Loss After Shift in Medicare Policy

docs.abstract: Tenet Healthcare reports first-qarter loss after changing its policy for billing Medicare for sickest patients; company adopted new policy for billing 'outlier payments,' which are special Medicare payments made to health care providers for patients who incur unusually high costs; says it will sell or consolidate 14 hospitals and cut 300 jobs in effort to reduce costs and increase profit margins; reports loss of $20 million compared to profit of $278 million year ago; revenue rose 2 percent, to $3.45 billion from $3.38 billion year earlier (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of senators reached agreement with Republican leaders today on a financial aid package for the states, adding a crucial Democratic vote to President Bush's plan for eliminating taxes on dividends. Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska, a fiscally conservative Democrat, said he would support the temporary repeal of the dividend tax favored by Mr. Bush's allies, now that Republican leaders had agreed to give $20 billion to struggling state governments. With at least three Republican senators balking at supporting the tax cut, Mr. Nelson's vote, along with that of Senator Zell Miller, Democrat of Georgia, could give Republicans 50 votes for the cut. Vice President Dick Cheney could then break the tie.

headline.main: With Plan for State Aid, Senate Republicans Gain Crucial Democratic Vote on Tax Cut

docs.abstract: Bipartisan group of senators reaches agreement with Republican leaders to give $20 billion to struggling state governments, prompting Sen Ben Nelson, fiscally conservative Democrat, to say he will now support temporary repeal of dividend tax favored by allies of Pres Bush (M)
